abstract.p: Liquid desiccant is an energy-saving, environmentally friendly and healthy means of air dehumidification. A liquid desiccant-based all-air air conditioning system is studied by simulation. Two different modes of air mixing between the return air and the fresh air are compared, that is mixing before and mixing after the liquid desiccant dehumidifier, respectively. System performance and total energy consumption of the two modes under different operation conditions are obtained. The results show that mixing air after dehumidification consumes less energy than mixing air before dehumidification. Coefficient of performance (COP) of the all-air system with air mixing after dehumidification is higher. The differences of COP and energy consumption between the two air mixing modes increase when the outdoor air temperature and relative humidity increase.

Practical application: Liquid desiccant based all-air system is quite suitable for museums, libraries and computer centres where water is not allowed to enter the space for property safety and strict thermal-hygrometric control is necessary. The results of this paper provide guidelines on the selection of air mixing modes in liquid desiccant-based all-air systems, considering energy consumption and system COP.

sec.title: 1 Introduction
sec.p: Liquid desiccant is an energy-efficient and environmentally friendly means of air dehumidification. In conventional air handling processes, the moisture in air is usually removed by cooling with temperature below the dew point of the process air, which may cause energy waste and poor Indoor Air Quality. Different from cooling dehumidification, liquid desiccant removes the moisture in air by absorbing it using strong desiccant aqueous solutions. The mass transfer driving force in the liquid dehumidification process is the water vapor pressure difference between the process air and the solution surface. Since latent load and sensible load can be removed separately, liquid desiccant technology is very suitable for application in advanced air conditioning systems with independent temperature and humidity control.

Since the liquid desiccant system was proposed firstly in 1953,1 a significant amount of research has been conducted on this promising dehumidification technology. The liquid desiccant-based air conditioning system has been one of the research hot topics.2–4 Previous studies of the liquid desiccant-based air conditioning system focused on independent fresh air handling system working in parallel with sensible cooling terminal equipment, such as dry coils and chilled ceiling.5–7 Liquid desiccant in the fresh air handling system is responsible for latent load removal and indoor humidity control, and sensible terminal equipment is responsible for sensible load removal and indoor temperature control. The liquid desiccant-based all-air air conditioning system has seldom been studied. However, all-air systems have been widely used for long time and have unique strengths. For example, all-air systems are preferred for museums, libraries and computer centres where water is not allowed to enter the space for property safety and strict thermal-hygrometric control is necessary.8 It is worthwhile to study the application of liquid desiccant in all-air systems. This article investigates the optimal system configuration of liquid desiccant-based all-air systems.

The dehumidifier and the regenerator in the simulated liquid desiccant-based all-air system in this study are both counter flow adiabatic types. The system uses lithium chloride as desiccant. Two possible modes of air mixing between the return air and the fresh air, that is mixing before and after the dehumidifier, respectively, are compared in terms of energy efficiency. The performance and energy consumption of the both modes under variable operation conditions are obtained. Practical implications of this study is discussed at the end of this article.

sec.title: 2 System description and performance simulation
sec.p:
Figure 1 is the schematic diagram of the liquid desiccant-based all-air system. In this system, the moisture is removed by liquid desiccant rather than by low temperature coolants. The proposed liquid desiccant-based all-air system can overcome all the problems caused by low temperature cooling dehumidification. There are two possible mixing modes between the fresh air and the return air in the system. One mode is shown as (a) in Figure 1. The fresh air and the return air are mixed before entering the liquid desiccant dehumidifier, and then the mixed air is dehumidified by the desiccant solution. The other mode is shown as (b) in thefigure. The fresh air is dehumidified by the liquid desiccant, and then mixed with the return air. In both modes, the dry mixed air is cooled to the supply air state using chilled water. Since the latent load has been removed by the liquid desiccant, the chilled water temperature can be higher than the dew point temperature of the supply air. Therefore, energy can be saved and indoor environment quality can be improved due to eliminating wet surface. Moreover, indoor temperature and humidity can be controlled independently and precisely. Figure 1
Schematic diagram of the liquid desiccant-based all-air system

The concentrated solution absorbs the moisture in the dehumidifier and becomes diluted. The diluted solution is re-concentrated in the regenerator and acquires the dehumidification capacity again. The moisture transfer driving force in both the dehumidifier and the regenerator is the water vapor pressure difference between the solution and the air. To enhance mass transfer, the diluted solution needs to be heated before entering the regenerator, and the concentrated solution needs to be cooled before entering the dehumidifier. A solution heat exchanger is used to recover the heat released during the dehumidification process. Low-grade heat sources are preferred for heating the diluted solution, such as solar energy and industrial waste heat.

The performance simulation is conducted based on the weather conditions in Hong Kong, where air conditioning accounts for a large percentage of total energy use due to its hot and humid climate. The application of liquid desiccant in Hong Kong has great energy-saving potential.9 In this simulation study, the highest humidity ratio (ωO) of 25.15 g/kg dry air in Hong Kong is selected as the base condition. The corresponding outdoor air dry bulb temperature (TO) is 29.6°C, and the relative humidity (RHO) is 94.9%. The design indoor air temperature (TR) is 23°C and the relative humidity (RHR) is 50%. The supply air state is fixed at the design condition. As the cooling temperature for sensible load removal can be raised in the liquid desiccant-based system, the set point of the supply air temperature (TS) is set as 18°C. The states of the outdoor air under base condition, the design values of the indoor air (return air) and the supply air are summarized in Table 1. Table 1
States of the indoor/outdoor air and the supply air (base condition)
Description Dry bulb temperature T (°C) Relative humidity RH (%) Humidity ratio ω (g/kg) Specific enthalpy h (kJ/kg)
O Fresh air 29.60 94.90 25.15 94.06
R Return air 23.00 50.00 8.75 45.39
S Supply air 18.00 65.49 8.42 39.43

A typical educational lecture theatre with an area of 100 m2 is simulated. The occupant density is 0.65 person/m2. According to the empirical load estimation in Hong Kong, the heat excess Q of indoor space is assumed to be15.1 kW. The indoor moisture excess W can beobtained according to the occupant number using Equation (1), (1)W=n'nτg where nτ is the total occupant number, g is the moisture dispersal of a adult male per hour and n′ is the percentage of men, women and children.

The supply air mass flow rate needed in the system is 2.514 kg/s, and the minimum fresh air required is 0.3354 kg/s according to ANSI/ASHRAE Standard 62.1.10 The corresponding minimum fresh air ratio is 13.34%. For the purpose of improving IAQ, the base fresh air ratio is set as 20% in this study.

The air handling processes of the two possible air mixing modes are depicted in psychrometric charts, respectively, as shown in Figure 2. Figure 2(a) shows the air handling process under the mode of air mixing before the dehumidifier. The mixed air (Point C), with the flow rate of 2.514 kg/s, is dehumidified in the liquid desiccant dehumidifier to the state of 8.41 g/kg dry air (Point D), which is the same as the supply air humidity. After dehumidification, the mixed air is cooled sensibly by the high temperature coolant to the supply air temperature (Point S). The psychrometric air handling process of the mode of mixing after the dehumidifier is shown in Figure 2(b), in which only the fresh air is dehumidified by the liquid desiccant. The dry fresh air after dehumidification is mixed with the return air. Since the humidity of the mixed air is identical to that of the supply air, the humidity of the air leaving the dehumidifier is lower than that of the air in the mode of mixing before the dehumidifier. When the fresh air ratio is 20%, to ensure the mixed air state to meet the humidity requirement, the humidity of the air leaving the dehumidifier should be 7.11 g/kg (Point D′). Then, the fresh air and the return air are mixed in the ratio of 1 to 4, shown as the line of RC′D′. The humidity of the mixed point (C′) is the same as that of the supply air. Similar to the mode of mixing before the dehumidifier, the mixed air is cooled by the high temperature coolant to the state of the supply air, which is a process of sensible cooling shown as line C′S. Finally, the air is delivered into the indoor space. Figure 2
Air handling processes of the two air mixing modes in the liquid desiccant-based all-air system

As for the liquid desiccant sub-system, the base states of the solution are 29.5°C and 36% of mass concentration. In the simulation, the size of the dehumidifier is identical in the two air-mixing modes. The dehumidifier is packed counter flow type with a height of 0.6 m and a section area of 0.8 m2. According to the authors’ previous study,7 the air humidity after dehumidification is sensitive to the variation of the inlet solution temperature in the dehumidifier, and regulating the solution inlet temperature to follow the latent load changing is feasible for the supply air humidity control. Therefore, in each case of simulation tests, the desiccant solution flow rate is kept fixed and the inlet solution temperature is adjusted. The solution flow rate is determined according to the minimum demand for moisture removal. The solution inlet states are 29.5°C and 36% of mass concentration. When the demand for moisture removal or equivalently the latent load increases, the inlet solution temperature is adjusted to lower to enhance the dehumidification ability so that the air humidity after dehumidification can be maintained. For each simulation test, the solution temperature atthe inlet of the dehumidifier to meet the requirement of moisture removal can be obtained by iteration in the mathematical model. In the iteration process, the flow rate of solution is fixed to that under the minimum latent load, the dehumidification capacity of solution is regulated by varying its temperature, when the air humidity after dehumidification reaches the set value, the solution temperature at the inlet of dehumidifier is obtained. The mathematical model is based on the NTU-based approach,11–13 and an analytical solution of the model reported in reference11 is adopted as follows, (3-1)ωa=ωin·eNTU(y-L)L+ω*·(1-eNTU(y-L)L)+(ωe,in-ω*)·1-eNTU(m*-1)(L-y)L1-m*eNTU(m*-1) (3-2)Le=FHFMCp,a (3-1)NTU=FMvALMair Where ωa is the humidity ratio of air at the section with height of y, L is the total height of the dehumidifier packing, ωe,in is humidity ratio in equilibrium with the desiccant solution at the inlet of dehumidifier, FH and FM are the heat transfer coefficient and mass transfer coefficient in the dehumidification process, respectively, Cp,a is the specific heat capacity of air, Mair is the mass flow rate of the air in the dehumidifier, v is the specificsurfacearea of the packing in dehumidifier, A is the cross-section area of the packing and ω* and m* are the calculation process variables, the details can be found in reference 11.

The calculation efficiency is satisfactory, and the simulation precision is acceptable as the deviations between the simulation results and experimental data in literature14 are less than 10%. To simplify the performance simulation process, the heating load of solution regeneration is obtained by the following: (3)Ereg=Mairr(ωin-ωout)ηreg where Ereg is the heating load of the desiccant solution regeneration, Mair is the mass flow rate of the air in the dehumidifier, r is the latent heat of vaporization of water, ωin and ωout are the air humidity ratios before and after dehumidification, respectively, and ηreg is the regeneration efficiency, which is set as 0.8 in this study.15

The flowchart for determining system performance is shown in Figure 3, which consists of the calculation processes of the two mixing modes. The basic principles of the calculation in both modes are the same. Firstly, the states of the air before dehumidification are determined. As the indoor latent load is entirely handled by the liquid desiccant solution, the humidity of the air at the outlet of the dehumidifier can be determined accordingly. Then, the base flow rate and the inlet temperature of the solution in the dehumidification process can be obtained through an iteration process. Meanwhile, the air temperature after dehumidification can be obtained from the numerical model. Finally, the energy consumption for solution regeneration, solution cooling and solution transportation can be calculated. Furthermore, the energy consumed in the air cooling and air transportation processes can be obtained. The total energy consumption (Etotal) in the proposed liquid desiccant-based air conditioning is: (4-1)Etotal=Ereg+Esol,cool+Eair,cool+Etran (4-2)Esol,cool=Msol,DE·Cp,sol·(Tsol,out,HX-Tsol,in,DE) (4-3)Eair,cool=Mair·Cp,air·(Tair,out,DE-TS) where Ereg is the energy consumption for solution regeneration, which can be obtained using Equation 3, Esol,cool and Eair,cool are the energy consumed in the solution cooling and air cooling processes, respectively, Etran is the energy consumption in transportation of the solution, the air and the chilled water, that is the fan and pump energy consumptions. Cp,sol and Cp,air are the specific heat capacities of the desiccant solution and the process air, respectively. Tsol,out,HX is the solution temperature before entering the dehumidifier. Tsol,in,DE is the solution temperature required at the inlet of the dehumidifier. Tair,out,DE and TS are the temperatures of the air after dehumidification and the supply air, respectively. Figure 3
Flowchart for determining system performances of the proposed system using the two air mixing modes, respectively

The COPS of the system in different air mixing modes can be calculated as follows: (5)Mode of mixing before DE: COP=Mair(hC-hS)Etotal/0.3 (6)Mode of mixing after DE:=Mair(hC'-hS)+RfrMair(hO-hD')Etotal/0.3 where Rfr is the fresh air ratio, h is the specific enthalpy of the air, 0.3 is the equivalent coefficient of electric power and thermal energy.4

sec.title: 3 Results and discussions
sec.p:
The energy performance of the two air mixing modes is tested under four different cases. Table 2 summarizes all test cases simulated in this study. Table 2

Case 1: Comparison of two mixing modes under base condition

Under the base condition specified in the article, that is the fresh air ratio is 20% and the temperate and relative humidity of the outdoor air are 29.6°C and 94.9%, respectively, the states of the mixed air and dehumidified air in the handling processes of the two different mixing modes are summarized in Table 3. The comparison between the two mixing modes under the base condition is listed in Table 4. In both mixing modes, the concentrated solution entering the dehumidifier has a temperature of 28°C and a mass concentration of 36%. The chilled water, with an inlet temperature of 13°C and an outlet temperature of 18°C, is used for sensibly cooling of air and desiccant solution. Although the states ofair at the inlet and outlet of the dehumidifier are different in the two modes as shown in the Table 3, the water condensation rates, as listed in Table 4, are nearly the same. Therefore, it can be concluded that the heating energy consumptions of the two modes in solution regeneration are also nearly the same, as the efficiency of regenerator is assumed fixed. As for the energy consumed in the air cooling process, it can be seen from Table 3, the enthalpy of the air before cooling in mode (b) is smaller than that in mode (a). However, the air states after cooling in two modes are the same as the supply air states, and the flow rates of the air are also the same. Therefore, the energy consumption for sensibly cooling air in mode (b) is less than that in mode (a). Moreover, since more air is handled in the dehumidifier when the fresh air and return air are mixed before dehumidification, more desiccant solution is thus required in mode (a). The desiccant solutions needed in the dehumidifier in mode (a) is 3.20 kg/s, while only 0.48 kg/s solution is needed in mode (b). However, the solution in both modes should be cooled from 29.5°C to 28°C, which means the energy consumptions in the solution cooling as well as the solution transportation in mode (a) are much more than those in mode (b). Therefore, under the base condition, when the fresh air and the return air are mixed after dehumidification, the energy consumptions for air cooling, solution cooling and solution transportation are all smaller compared with those in the mode of air mixed before dehumidification. As a result, the total energy consumption of the mode (b) is 19.7% lower than that of mode (a) as shown in Table 4. Table 4

Next, the performances and energy consumptions of the two air mixing modes are analyzed under varied working conditions. Under each of the three cases, one of the working conditions, including the outdoor air temperature, the outdoor air relative humidity and the fresh air ratio, are varied separately, while the other two are kept the same as those under the base condition. When the latent load changes with the variation in working conditions, adjusting the solution temperature at the inlet of the dehumidifier is adopted as the outlet air humidity control method.
Case 2: Comparison of two modes under various fresh air ratios

Table 5 gives the results when the fresh air ratio increases from 20% to 30% and the outdoor air temperature and humidity are the same as those under base condition. In the figures, the ‘before’ and ‘after’ in the legend of figures indicate the two air mixing modes, that is mixing before and after the dehumidifier, respectively. It can be seen that, with the increase in the fresh air ratio, the solution temperatures at the inlet of the dehumidifier in both modes decrease. It is because that the larger the latent load is, the higher the required dehumidification capacity is, and the cooler the solution is, the higher the dehumidification capacity is. Therefore, the energy consumptions for solution cooling in both modes increase with the increase in the fresh air ratio. It also can be seen that when the fresh air ratio is over 26%, the solution temperature needed in mode (a) gradually becomes higher than that in mode (b). However, in mode (b), that is mixing after dehumidification, as the solution flow rate is much smaller than that in mode (a), it can be deduced that the energy consumption for solution cooling is still much lower than that in the mode of mixing before dehumidification. In addition, the air temperature before sensible cooling in mode (a) decreases gradually with the increase in the fresh ratio, while it rises gradually in mode (b), which means the energy consumption for air cooling increases in the mode of mixing after dehumidification and drops in the mode of mixing before dehumidification. However, as the air temperature before cooling is higher in mode (a), the energy consumption in air sensible cooling will be much larger in this mode. Table 5

The variation of the total energy consumption when the fresh air ratio varies is shown in Figure 4(a). It is consistent with above analysis of the data in Table 5, that is the energy consumptions for the solution cooling and air sensible cooling in the mode of mixing before dehumidification are much larger than those in the other mode. Besides, as the flow rate of desiccant solution in mode (a) is almost 7 times higher than that in mode (b), the energy consumption for solution transportation will be obviously larger in mode (a). The total energy consumption, as can be seen in the figure, is much larger when the fresh air and return air are mixed before dehumidification. Moreover, with the increase in the fresh air ratio, although the energy consumption for airsensible cooling drops in the mode of mixing before dehumidification and increases in the mode of mixing after dehumidification, the energy consumption for solution cooling increases more sharply in the former mode. As a result, the energy consumption difference between the two modes increases gradually, when the fresh air ratio increases from 20% to 30%, the difference in energy consumption between the two modes increases from 3.98 kW to 6.56 kW. Figure 4
Energy consumption and coefficient of performance (COP) of the proposed system in different mixing modes when fresh air ratio varies

Figure 4(b) shows the comparison of COP between the two air mixing modes with the increase of the fresh air ratio. As shown in Figure 4(a), the total energy consumed in the mode (a) is lower than that in the mode (b). Meanwhile, it can be seen from Table 5, the total heat removal of the air handling process in the mode (b) is always almost 9 kW higher than that in the mode (a). Therefore, the ratio of the total heat removal to the energy consumption, that is the COP of the proposed system, is higher in the mode (b) than that of the mode (a). In addition, when the fresh air ratio increases, more moisture in air needs to be removed, which means the latent load increases sharply. Hence, the heating loads of solution regeneration, the cooling loads of the solution and the total energy consumptions all increase in both modes. However, it can be seen from the data in Table 5 that the sensible load of air cooling decreases in the mode ofmixing before dehumidification while decreases in the other mode. In general, the increase in the total load, that is the sum of latent load and sensible load, is larger thanthat in the total energy consumption. Therefore, the COPs in both modes increase slightly when the fresh air ratio grows.
Case 3: Comparison of two modes under various outdoor air temperatures

Figure 5 shows the energy consumption and the COP of the two mixing modes when only the outdoor air temperature varies, which increases from 25°C to 29.5°C. The relative humidity of the outdoor air and the fresh ratio are the same as those in the base condition. As mentioned in Part 2, the solution flow rate in this test case is fixed and is determined according to the minimum latent load, and the inlet temperature of the desiccant solution is regulated to follow the changing latent load and to maintain the supply air humidity. The solution flow rates in the modes of mixing before and after dehumidification are 1.02 and 0.94 kg/s, respectively. It can be seen that the energy consumptions increase in both modes, which is because the latent load grows when the outdoor air temperature increases and the relative humidity fixes. The energy consumption for solution transportation is higher in the mode of mixing before dehumidification due to the larger flow rate. Moreover, when the outdoor air temperature increases from 25°C to 29.5°C, to ensure the humidity of the process air after dehumidification, the desiccant solution temperature should be decreased to enhance its dehumidification capacity. Thus, the solution inlet temperature in the mode of mixing before dehumidification drops from 29.5°C to 26.34°C, while that in the mode of mixing after dehumidification slightly decreases from 29.5°C to 29.27°C. Therefore, the energy consumption for solution cooling in the former mode is much larger than that in the latter one. Besides, as the airtemperature before sensible cooling in the mode of mixing before dehumidification is higher than that in the other mode, the energy consumption for air cooling in the former mode is thus also larger. There are nearly no difference in the water condensation rates between the two modes, hence the energy consumptions for solution regeneration are nearly the same. In sum, the total energy consumption is larger in the proposed system with air mixing mode of before dehumidification, as shown in Figure 5(a). Furthermore, the difference of total energy consumption between the two modes is larger when the outdoor air temperature is higher, when the outdoor air temperature increases from 25°C to 29.5°C, the energy consumption difference between the two modes increases from 1.46 kW to 2.71 kW, which mainly attributes to the sharp increase in the energy consumption for solution cooling in the mode of mixing before dehumidification. Figure 5
Energy consumption and coefficient of performance (COP) of the proposed system in different mixing modes when outdoor air temperature varies

The variation in the COP with the increase of the outdoor air temperature can be seen in Figure 5(b). In general, the COP increases with the increase in the outdoor air temperature in both modes, which means the total heat removal of the proposed system increases more sharply than the energy consumption does. The COP of the proposed system with air mixing after dehumidification is higher than that with air mixing before dehumidification, because the total energy consumption in the former mode is less. In addition, withthe increase in the outdoor air temperature, the COP increases more quickly in the mode of mixing after dehumidification. The main reason is that the total energy consumption insuch mode increases more gently thandoes in the mode of mixing before dehumidification.
Case 4: Comparison of two modes under various outdoor air relative humidities

Figure 6 shows the comparisons of the energy consumption and the COP between different mixing modes when the outdoor air relative humidity varies. The solution flow rates in the modes of mixing before and after dehumidification are 0.94 and 0.99 kg/s, respectively. With the increase in the outdoor air relative humidity, the moisture to be removed in the air, or the latent load, increases, which leads to more energy consumed in regenerating and cooling the solution. Therefore, in both air mixing modes, the energy consumptions increase with the increase in the outdoor air relative humidity. As the increase in the total heat removal of the proposed system is larger than that in the energy consumption, the COP increases when the outdoor air relative humidity increases. Figure 6
Energy consumption and coefficient of performance (COP) of the proposed system in different mixing modes when outdoor air relative humidity varies

It can be seen from Figure 6, the energy consumption in the mode of air mixing before dehumidification is larger than that in the mode of air mixing after dehumidification, and the COP of the former mode is smaller than that of the latter one. It is because the less energy consumption for air and solution cooling as well as for the chilled water transportation in the latter mode. When the two air streams are mixed before dehumidification, the temperature of the dehumidified air is higher, thus the energy consumption for air sensible cooling is larger than that when the two air streams are mixed after dehumidification. The mode of mixing after dehumidification consumes more energy for solution transportation because of the larger solution flow rate. According to the simulation results, the solution inlet temperature needed in the mode of mixing before dehumidification is much lower than that in the other mode. Therefore, the energy consumption for solution cooling in the former mode is still higher than that in the latter mode, although the solution flow rate is smaller in the former one. Furthermore, the higher the outdoor air relative humidity is, the larger the difference on energy consumptions for solution cooling between the two air mixing modes is, with the outdoor air relative humidity increases from 70% to 92%, the energy consumption difference varies from 1.61 kW to 2.59 kW. Therefore, the differences in total energy consumption and COP between the two air mixing modes become larger with the increase in the outdoor air relative humidity.

sec.title: 4 Conclusions
sec.p: A liquid desiccant-based all-air air-conditioning system is studied by simulation. The system is quite suitable for air conditioned spaces where water is not allowed to enter andrequires strict and independent control of indoor temperature and humidity. The energy consumptions and COPs of the proposed system with different air mixing modes, that is air mixing before and after dehumidification, are compared under variable working conditions. When the latent load changes with the variation in working conditions, the method of adjusting the solution temperature at the inlet of the dehumidifier is adopted for the humidity control. The main findings and application implications are summarized as follows.

When the fresh air and the return air are mixed after dehumidification in the proposed liquid desiccant-based all-air system, under the base condition, the total energy consumption is 19.7% lower than that when they are mixed before dehumidification. Under varied conditions, with the increases in the fresh air ratio, outdoor air temperature and relative humidity, when the air are mixed after dehumidification, the total energy consumption is always lower and the COP is always higher. However, the difference in the energy consumption between the two air mixing modes becomes larger with the increase inthe latent load of air handling process. When the fresh air ratio increases from 20% to 30%, the difference in energy consumption of the two modes increases from 3.98 kW to 6.56 kW. When the outdoor air temperature increases from 25°C to 29.5°C, the energy consumption difference between the two modes increases from 1.46 kW to 2.71 kW. While the outdoor air relative humidity increases from 70% to 92%, the energy consumption difference varies from 1.61 kW to 2.59 kW. As a result, the differences in the COP between the two mixing modes are larger when the fresh air ratio as well as the outdoor air temperature and relative humidity are higher.

As far as energy consumption and COP are concerned, the system configuration of mixing air after dehumidification has better performance. Considering precise control of the space humidity, the mode of mixing air before dehumidification seems to have some advantages over the mode of mixing air after dehumidification, because the humidity of the air leaving the dehumidifier in the former mode has a more straightforward influence on the space humidity. Robust control approach for the latter mode can certainly improve its control performance. It is possible to achieve optimal performances in both energy consumption and system reliability in terms of control by further study.
